bioghist.p: The Mutual Assurance Company for Insuring Houses from Loss by Fire, familiarly known as Green Tree, was organized in Philadelphia in 1784, in order to make fire insurance available to those citizens wishing to have trees in front of their homes. The company was founded in response to a change in by-laws of the city's first insurance company, the Philadelphia Contributionship. In 1781, The Contributionship excluded houses with trees nearby from coverage. The Green Tree's most important contribution to American insurance underwriting was the introduction in 1801 of the perpetual policy. Prior to that time, policies were written for a seven-year term, renewable without additional depost. The company began this policy not only to save on administrative costs but also to avoided paying the stamp tax levied in 1799 during the turmoil of the quasi-war with France. During the late 1980s and early 1990s, the company purchased other underwriters, which extended their range of coverage, including flood, ocean and inland marine, private passenger and commercial automobile insurances. In 1996, The Mutual Assurance Company and its various subsidiaries merged into National Grange Mutual Insurance Company, headquartered in Keene, New Hampshire.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of papers arranged in five major sections: 1) histories of the company, research notes, and 18th century general papers; 2) minutes of meetings and related records; 3) cancelled surveys and cancelled policies; 4) general papers, including correspondence; and 5) financial records and receipts. Included in these papers is one box of newspaper clippings, most from the late 18th and 19th centuries, including the 1784 article in The Independent Gazetteer, announcing the meeting of several prominent men of the city that led to the company's founding. Volumes include treasurer's accounts, cash books, ledgers, and street registers as well as original and typescript copies of the minutes of the Board of Trustees' meetings and annual reports to the Pennsylvania Insurance Department. In addition to these, there are approximately 50 atlases covering properties in the several Pennsylvania counties in the Delaware Valley area as well as properties along the Main Line, North Pennsylvania, Bound Brook and Pennsylvania Railroads, circa 1870-1937. There are also several maps of the various counties. The collection also includes prints, drawings and house plans and photographs, mostly of board members, as well as video and audio tapes, several of which are oral histories, with transcripts. Company-related videotapes and tapes of radio advertisements are also available. There is also one box of various logo stamps and corporate seals. Microfilm copy of records up to 1965, made for security purposes, is stored at Arca Data Security, King of Prussia. An inventory is included in the finding aid. Cancelled policies and surveys of the mid-1950s were made by the National Park Service for research purposes.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
